qas.question: What is the Sanskrit grammatical tradition?
In what period did Vyakarana begin?
How many sutras are in the Astadhyayi?
Who composed Vartikas on the Panini sutras?
What is the abbreviated alphabet called?
What was composed about a century before Panini?
Who lived three centuries before Panini?
What is based on 12 Shiva sutras?
What is Pratyahara a partial abbreviation of?

context: The Sanskrit grammatical tradition, <a0_0>Vyākaraṇa<a0_0/>, one of the six Vedangas, began in the <a1_0>late Vedic<a1_0/> period and culminated in the Aṣṭādhyāyī of Pāṇini, which consists of <a2_0>3990 sutras<a2_0/> (ca. fifth century BCE). About a century after Pāṇini (around 400 BCE), <a3_0>Kātyāyana<a3_0/> composed <b5_0>Vārtikas<b5_0/> on the Pāṇini sũtras. <b6_0>Patanjali<b6_0/>, who lived three centuries after Pāṇini, wrote the <b7_0>Mahābhāṣya<b7_0/>, the "Great Commentary" on the Aṣṭādhyāyī and Vārtikas. Because of these three ancient Vyākaraṇins (grammarians), this grammar is called Trimuni Vyākarana. To understand the meaning of the sutras, Jayaditya and Vāmana wrote a commentary, the <b8_0>Kāsikā<b8_0/>, in 600 CE. Pāṇinian grammar is based on 14 Shiva sutras (aphorisms), where the whole <b9_0>mātrika (alphabet)<b9_0/> is abbreviated. This abbreviation is called the <a4_0>Pratyāhara<a4_0/>.
